dominantly originated fromthe outdoors. Senseware nodes do not make correc-
tions to the raw measurements and are calibrated with the ATD.
levels with an accuracy of ±50 ppm. In Wurster
placed in two representative locations. Senseware contact monitors
mounted on the windows in Wurster Hall to detect window position. Detection was binary
(i.e., open/closed) and did not provide information on opening area or window angle.
Prior to deployment, Clarity Inc. and Senseware PM
with Grimmaerosol spectrometer (model 11-A, GRIMMAerosol Technik GmbH, Ainring,
Germany) that provides time-and size-resolved data for aerosol particles. Clarity and Sense-
compared to Grimmmeasurements at ambient PM
, which is within the given accuracy for each node.
We selected two buildings, 1608 4th Street Building (mechanically ventilated) and Wurster
Hall (mixed-mode ventilation operating as fully naturally ventilated during the study period)
to deploy sensors. Both buildings were located in Berkeley (California). In March 2018, we
sensors in both buildings and win-
dow contact sensors in Wurster Hall. Berkeley was affected by air pollution fromthe Chico
of data collected during the Chico Camp fire.
is a mechanically ventilated building with
centralized heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) system. The HVAC systemuti-
lizes three stages of air filtration: the first stage of filtration is by a MERV 8 pleated filter, the
second stage is the Gas Phase filter, and the final filter stage is a high-efficiency MERV 13 filter.
decay profile during non-occupied hours were used to calculate infiltration
rates (details in the Supporting Information). Infiltration was below 0.3 air exchanges per hour
suggesting that the building is airtight without operable windows. The building has approxi-
Mixed-mode building with seasonal changeover, meaning that the building
is fully naturally ventilated when the building is operating in cooling, as was the case during
the Chico Camp fire. The building relies on operable windows for ventilation and cooling. The
building has a high level of infiltration, as shown by typical CO
normal operation. The building has approximately 300 full-time occupants.
2.3.1 Placement of outdoor and indoor sensors.
floor. Floors had the same layouts; therefore, considering the available
number of sensors, we placed all sensors on the 3
floor. We placed one outdoor PM
(Clarity node) on the roof of the building, and 15 PM
Clarity node) at different indoor locations.
in the Supporting Information provides a
floor plan with sensor locations in the 4
Street. Each of the floors consists of large open floor
office area with high partitions housing 71 stations, six private offices, two teammeeting
rooms, one large teammeeting room, and two phone booths. We placed one PM
sensor in the private office, and the remaining sensors in the open floor office. We wanted
to measure if the building envelope was leaky, so we placed PM
with windows so that we can conservatively estimate building operation.
IoT sensing tool for determining building resilience
